text: Which of the following timelines would be included in the perinatal period as per WHO? 37th week of gestation to 28 days after birth 20th week of gestation to 7 days after birth 28th week of gestation to 28 days after birth 22nd week of gestation to 7 days after birth
explanation:
:
The WHO states that the perinatal period commences at 22 completed weeks and ends at seven completed days after birth - 154 days. It corresponds to when the fetus weighs 500g or more.
This definition is not to be confused with the period used for the calculation of the perinata mortality rate (PMR). To calculate the PMR, a fetal weight above 1000 g is considered, which is achieved at 28 weeks of gestation. Therefore, for all statistical purposes, internationa comparisons, and calculation of perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is considered.

Perinatal period: from the 22nd week.
Perinatal mortality rate calculation: from the 28th week.
The neonatal period is defined as the first 28 days after birth. Infancy is defined as the first year of life.
The image below shows various time periods. Only the time period for perinatal mortality and the perinatal period are different as shown in the image. For others, corresponding mortality rates are calculated using the same time periods shown.

text: You would classify a baby as post-term if it is born after 40 weeks of completed gestation 40 weeks and 2 days 41 weeks of completed gestation 42 weeks of completed gestation
explanation:
:
Post-term infants are those born after 42 completed weeks of gestation, as calculated from the mother’s last menstrual period, regardless of weight at birth.

:

A low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <2.5 Kg.

text: Reena, a 34-year-old lady with gestation diabetes mellitus delivers an LGA baby at 37 weeks. What would the birth weight of this child be? >75th Percentile >97th Percentile >90th Percentile >95th Percentile
explanation:
:
Infants with birth weight greater than the 90th percentile for their gestational age are called large for gestational age (LGA) babies.




Maternal diabetes and obesity are predisposing factors for LGA babies. They have a higher incidence of:
Birth injuries:
Brachial plexus injury
Phrenic nerve injury
Cephalohematomas
Hypoglycemia
Polycythemia
Congenital heart disease

text: As the intern assisting in the labor room, you are tasked with administering Vitamin K to the term newborns with no complications. Which of the following dose and route would you use for administration? 0.5 - 1 mg IM 5 - 10 mg IV 1 - 5 mg IV 0.1 - 0.5 mg IM
explanation:
:
All newborn infants are to be administered vitamin K at a dose of 0.5–1 mg intramuscularly, to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (HDN).
However, for newborns with vitamin K deficiency, the dose of vitamin K administered is 1–5 mg intravenously.

text: A term neonate born by normal vaginal delivery is diagnosed with hypothermia. Which of the following is not a physiological response for heat regulation in this baby? Shivering Breakdown of brown fat with noradrenaline secretion Increased muscular activity Cutaneous vasoconstriction
explanation:
:
Neonates do not generate heat by shivering.
Heat production in neonates happens by increasing the metabolic rate and oxygen consumption by releasing norepinephrine, which results in non-shivering thermogenesis through
beta-oxidation of brown fat. This sympathetic surge also causes cutaneous vasoconstriction.

Increased physical activity - crying, increased body movements, and muscular activity also contribute to thermogenesis.
Preterm and small-for-gestational-age (SGA) infants have scanty brown fat stores.

text: You are conducting the routine newborn assessment of a 2.3 kg baby born 10 minutes back. You would classify the neonate as having cold stress if you notice the body temperature to be: 35.4-36.0 °C 33.4-34.0 °C 34.4-35.4 °C 36.0-36.4 °C
explanation:
:
A temperature of 36.0 to 36.4°C categorizes a neonate as having cold stress.
An infant’s normal body temperature is 36.5 to 37.5 °C. It is measured in the apex of the baby's axilla by holding the thermometer for at least 3 minutes.
Hypothermia is an axillary temperature of <36.5 °C.
Cold stress: 36.0 to 36.4 °C
Moderate hypothermia: 32 to 35.9 °C
Severe hypothermia: <32 °C
Hyperthermia is an axillary temperature of >37.5 °C.

text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below. Which of the following statements about this method is false? Can be continued at home Safety and thermal protection is equivalent to incubators Reduces severe morbidity in the newborns Should be performed only by the mother
explanation:
:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.
KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components—
Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
Early discharge and ambulatory care.
Support for mother and family for child care. Evidence shows that-
It is as good as incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
Humanization of neonatal care
Promoted bonding between mother and child E igibility criteria for KMC:
It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.
Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation

Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC.
Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.
The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.
KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation. Note:
Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

text: While examining a healthy term neonate, you notice that the baby passes greenish-black colored stools. This color is due to - Bilirubin Biliverdin Meconium Gut flora of neonate
explanation:
:
The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to biliverdin.
Meconium is a dark, sticky material that is normally present in the intestine at birth and passed in the feces after birth. It is detected in the ileum at about 70–85 days of fetal life and begins to fill the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of the meconium is the consequence of the bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract. The main component

responsible for the greenish color of the meconium is biliverdin (a pigment formed from the oxidation of bilirubin).
Up to the 22nd week of gestation, the intestinal content is not greenish and for this reason, fetal defecation would not stain the amniotic fluid. The production of biliverdin starts over the next few weeks or at a time closer to labor, probably due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system. Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of the stools.
Neonates do not harbor gut flora at birth.

text: When does the parachute reflex disappear? At 3 months At 6 months At birth and reappears at 9 months Never
explanation:
:
The parachute reflex has its onset at 7–8 months of age. It is fully developed by 10-11 months of age and remains throughout life.
It can be evoked by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. The arms will spontaneously extend to break the infant’s fall.
This reflex is a prerequisite to walking.

text: A 6-day old infant is being examined. While checking the reflexes, a brisk Moro's reflex is noted. Which of the following conditions is a likely cause for this? Kernicterus Stage III hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) Hypoglycemia Erb's palsy
explanation:
:
A brisk Moro reflex can be seen in neonates with hypoglycemia.
In hypoglycemic babies, there is an activation of the autonomic system, which results in jitteriness. Newborns often exhibit this as an exaggerated Moro reflex.
The Moro reflex is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness. It is elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fa backward onto the examiner’s hand.
An animated gif of normal response to Moro's reflex where there is symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities is shown below


The Moro reflex disappears by 6 months of age in normal infants.
Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS
Stage III HIE
Kernicterus
Asymmetric Moro reflex: feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease
Fractured clavicle
Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
Hemiparesis Brisk Moro reflex:
Neonatal hypoglycemia
Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
Stage I HIE
Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:
Hydranencephaly
Severe micrencephaly
Moro reflex in different stages of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE):
Stage I HIE (mild): Brisk
Stage II HIE (moderate): Weak/incomplete
Stage III HIE (severe): Absent
Option A: In kernicterus, there is a deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brain stem. Hence, the Moro reflex is absent
Option C: In stage III HIE, the muscles are flaccid and the infant is comatose. Thus, the Moro reflex is absent.
Option D: Erb's palsy results from an injury to the brachial plexus. So, the reflex is absent on the side of injury as the nerve supplying the muscles involved (efferent of the reflex) is affected.

text: You are demonstrating findings in a pediatric OSCE examination on a 4-day old neonate. On turning the baby's head to the left, you obtain the finding as shown below. At what age does this reflex normally disappear? 6 months 9 months 4 months 5 months
explanation:
:
Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) disappears by 6 months postnatally.
The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated and flexion of the contralateral arm).

An obligatory tonic neck response, in which the infant becomes “stuck” in the fencing posture, is always abnormal and implies a CNS disorder.

text: A first-time mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature. On microscopic examination, these papular lesions on an erythematous base will reveal Eosinophils Neutrophils Giant Cells Lymphocytes
explanation:
:
The given clinical complex describes a case of erythema neonatorum. Wright stained smear of the contents of the pustule will show an abundance of eosinophils.
They are papular lesions on an erythematous base, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. They are seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for up to a week, after which they resolve spontaneously.
Neutrophils are seen in pustular melanosis.

text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for a well-baby check-up. A lesion that was present since birth is noticed as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? Dermal melanocytosis Salmon patch Neonatal pustular melanosis Harlequin colour change
explanation:
:
The above image shows Mongolian spots or dermal melanocytosis.
Mongolian spots are benign blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.
These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

Detailed Explanations
Solution to Question 1:
The image shows the presence of a single umbilical artery which is associated with an increased risk for an occult renal anomaly.

The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. Anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries.
Trisomy 18 is a common association.



Solution to Question 2:
A ponderal index of <2 suggests asymmetric intrauterine growth
restriction. Asymmetric IUGR is associated with a brain-sparing effect, unlike symmetric IUGR, where there is no sparing of head growth.
Ponderal index = Birth weight (gm)/Length (cm)3 x 100.
It is a weight-height-related parameter used as an indicator of fetal growth status.


Solution to Question 3:
A ponderal index of 1.75 suggests intrauterine growth restriction. Gestational diabetes usually presents with fetal macrosomia.
Maternal factors associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR):
Hypertension/renal disease
Diabetes with placental vasculopathy
Hypoxemia
Malnutrition
Chronic illness
Sickle cell anemia
Drugs (narcotics, alcohol, cigarettes, cocaine)

Solution to Question 4:
Thick cartilage with a stiff ear in a newborn is a sign of maturity (not prematurity).
No creases on the sole, insignificant breast nodule, and empty scrotum are all physical signs of prematurity in a newborn.
Note:
Abundant lanugo hair is not discriminatory evidence of prematurity. This is because neonates of diabetic mothers born as a term or even post-term have abundant lanugo hair, especially over the pinna and upper back.







Solution to Question 5:
The physical sign of an infant born post-term (43 weeks) in association with presumed placental insufficiency is abundant hair (not scanty hair).
Infants born post-term in association with presumed placental insufficiency may have various physical signs, together termed as postmaturity syndrome (or dysmaturity syndrome).
These include:
Desquamation, pale skin, and long nails.
Loose skin around the thighs and buttocks.
Meconium-stained nails, skin, vernix, and umbilical cord.
Presence of placental membranes.



Solution to Question 6:
Anemia is not a complication of post-maturity. Polycythemia may be seen in neonates born after 42 weeks of gestation.
Complications of post-maturity include:
Perinatal depression
Meconium aspiration
Persistent pulmonary hypertension
Hypoglycemia
Hypocalcemia

Polycythemia



Solution to Question 7:
The most likely diagnosis is caput succedaneum.
Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp, involving the presenting part in a vertex delivery. It may extend across the midline and crosses suture lines.
Option A: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after
birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.
Option C: Subgaleal hemorrhages occur with the rupture of emissary veins, which connect the dural sinuses with the superficial veins of the scalp. Blood accumulates between the epicranial aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum and resolves over 2-3 weeks. Often associated with vacuum-assisted delivery.
Option D: Epidural hemorrhages, usually traumatic in origin, are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or occur as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.





Solution to Question 8:
The area marked B represents a cephalohematoma. It is not a swelling of the soft tissues of the scalp.
Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.

Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat the associated hyperbilirubinemia (resorption of blood takes place by the breakdown of RBCs).



Other markings-
A- Caput succedaneum. It is a diffuse ecchymotic or edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears with the first week of life.
C- Sub-galeal hemorrhage. This a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It is a large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can also occur in hereditary coagulopathies and in association with skull fractures.
D- Epidural hemorrhage. Usually traumatic in origin, these are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.



Solution to Question 9:
Left-hand paralysis with ipsilateral ptosis and miosis in a newborn suggests a diagnosis of Klumpke's paralysis associated with Horner syndrome.
There is an injury to the 7th-8th cervical nerves and the 1st thoracic nerve. This produces
a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected, and the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1 thoracic root are also injured.
Option A: Erb–Duchenne paralysis affects the 5th and 6th cervical nerves. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination. Moro's reflex is absent on the affected side.

Option B: Phrenic nerve palsy (3, 4, and 5 cervical nerves) results in diaphragmatic paralysis. It is characterized by cyanosis and irregular and labored breathing.
Option C: Horner's syndrome is characterized by miosis, ptosis, enophthalmos, anhydrosis, and loss of ciliospinal reflex.





Solution to Question 10:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of Erb–Duchenne paralysis. The injury is limited to the 5th and 6th cervical nerve roots.
The characteristic position consists of adduction and internal rotation of the arm with pronation of the forearm. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination.
There is an asymmetric Moro's Reflex

Note:
In shoulder dystocia, the most common nerve injury is to the C5-6 nerve root. The most common bone to fracture is the clavicle.





Solution to Question 11:
The above pattern of jaundice is suggestive of physiological jaundice/icterus neonatorum. It is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver.
It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks on the 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.
Rh incompatibility between maternal and fetal red blood cells leads to pathological jaundice.


Note:
Depth of jaundice (degree of yellowness) should be carefully noted (light staining as lemon-yellow; deep staining as orange-yellow), as it is an important indicator of the level of jaundice. Earlier, the involvement of soles and palms indicated severe jaundice but deep yellow staining (even in absence of yellow soles or palms) may be associated with severe jaundice.



Solution to Question 12:
Jaundice associated with a rise in bilirubin level at a rate of <5 mg/dL/24 hours suggests physiological jaundice.
Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:
Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth
Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infan
Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level
	Total serum bilirubin levels above the expected normal range; jaundice seen in he mid-abdominal region ( 15 mg/dL) and soles ( 20 mg/dL)
Total serum bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy
Total serum bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy



Solution to Question 13:
ABO incompatibility is the most common cause of hemolytic disease of newborns and affects the firstborn. It is usually mild and subclinical.
This incompatibility between the mother and fetus generally results in milder disease than Rh incompatibility does.
It arises when a mother with blood group type O becomes pregnant with a fetus of different blood type (A/B). The mother's serum contains naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B, which can cross the placenta and cause hemolysis of fetal RBCs.
Although antibodies against A and B factors occur without previous immunization (natural antibodies), they are usually IgM, which do not cross the placenta. However, IgG antibodies to A antigen may be present, and these do cross the placenta, resulting in A-O iso-immune hemolytic disease in the first-born infant (A-O is more common than B-O).



Solution to Question 14:
The most effective range of wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia is 460–490 nm (blue-green light).

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms:
Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by
forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state.
Reversible photo-isomerization reaction: converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation.
Photo-oxidation: minor method







Solution to Question 15:
Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for pathological jaundice in neonates.
It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy.
Tolazoline is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist that produces systemic and pulmonary vasodilatation, which is used to correct pulmonary artery vasospasm when it causes severe right-left shunting soon after birth.
Tromethamine is an organic buffer used in the management of metabolic acidosis.



Solution to Question 16:
The bronze baby syndrome is a dark, grayish-brown skin discoloration in infants undergoing phototherapy; it mainly occurs in infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia as an adverse effect of

phototherapy.
Despite the bronze baby syndrome, phototherapy can continue if needed. Other complications of Phototherapy:
Loose stools
Erythematous macular rash

Solution to Question 17:
The cut-off for the treatment of neonatal hypoglycemia to start IV glucose is a blood glucose level of <40 mg/dL.
Neonatal hypoglycemia can be suspected when the blood glucose is <45 mg/dL. Clinically in neonates, hypoglycemia can be asymptomatic or symptomatic. The neonate presents with tremors, cyanosis, convulsions, apneic spells, tachypnea, weak and high-pitched cry, lethargy, difficulty in feeding, episodes of sweating, sudden pallor, hypothermia, and rarely cardiac arrest.
Management in symptomatic neonates:
Blood glucose <40mg/dL: IV glucose infusion
Blood glucose <25mg/dL: Bolus IV dextrose 1-2 mL/kg followed by infusion at the rate of 5-8mL/kg/min.
Management in asymptomatic neonates:
Breastfeeding within 30 minutes
Start IV glucose therapy if blood glucose <35 mg/dL
Recheck blood glucose before the next feeding
Continue skin-to-skin care
Evaluation for other underlying illnesses
The desired target glucose value is >50mg/dL and blood glucose should be rechecked until three normal values.
